Idiom (Tuvalu): E lavea ne te la te mea lilo
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: The truth will eventually be revealed; secrets cannot be hidden forever.
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: Truth always comes out in the end.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Originates from seafaring communities where sunlight was used metaphorically to represent clarity and revelation.
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Tuvalu): e laˈβea ne te la te ˈmea ˈlilo
First Example Sentence: Aua te fakasao ne koe au mea, e lavea ne te la te mea lilo.
Second Example Sentence: E se mafai o fakalilifu te mea sese; e lavea ne te la te mea lilo.
Third Example Sentence: I te taimi tonu, e lavea ne te la te mea lilo.

Idiom (Tuvalu): Ko te nofo fakamā, e se maua te ika
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: If you are too shy or hesitant, you will miss opportunities.
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: You must be bold to achieve success.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Draws from fishing life in Tuvalu, where patience and initiative determine one’s catch.
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Tuvalu): ko te ˈnofo fakaˈma e se ˈmaua te ˈika
First Example Sentence: E se maua ne koe te galuega ke nofo fakamā, e se maua te ika.
Second Example Sentence: Ko taku matua e fai mai, ‘Ke galue malosi, ke se nofo fakamā.’
Third Example Sentence: I te fono, ne fai atu te pule, ‘Ko te nofo fakamā, e se maua te ika.’

Idiom (Tuvalu): Ko te vai e mālū, e loloto
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Quiet people often possess deep wisdom.
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: Wise people don’t always speak much.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Metaphor derived from the ocean’s calm surface concealing its depth.
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Tuvalu): ko te ˈvai e ˈmaːlu e loˈloto
First Example Sentence: E iloa ne au a ia e fai mai se tino poto – ko te vai e mālū, e loloto.
Second Example Sentence: Ko te tagata e se faipati malosi, e masani o poto – ko te vai e mālū, e loloto.
Third Example Sentence: Ne fakaaoga ne te tusi te faaupuga ‘ko te vai e mālū, e loloto’ mō te tagata poto.

Idiom (Tuvalu): E se mālie te fale kae seai se loto fāmili
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: A house without love and unity is not a happy home.
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: A home is happy only when there is family love.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Reflects communal Tuvalu values emphasizing kinship and unity.
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Tuvalu): e se ˈmaːlie te ˈfale kae seˈai se ˈloto ˈfaːmili
First Example Sentence: E se mālie te fale kae seai se loto fāmili i loto.
Second Example Sentence: Ko te tamā e fai atu, ‘E se mālie te fale kae seai se loto fāmili.’
Third Example Sentence: Ne lagona ne au te fakatau fakamālie, e se mālie te fale kae seai se loto fāmili.

Idiom (Tuvalu): E tasi te matagi, e tokouke te tino e aafia
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: One event can affect many people.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Stems from island experiences where storms affect entire communities.
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Tuvalu): e ˈtasi te ˈmatagi e tokoˈuke te ˈtino e aˈafia
First Example Sentence: E tasi te matagi, e tokouke te tino e aafia, e pei o te fakalavelave i Nanumea.
Second Example Sentence: Ko te fakalavelave e tasi, e tokouke e aafia – e tasi te matagi.
Third Example Sentence: Ne fai atu te faipule, ‘E tasi te matagi, e tokouke te tino e aafia.’

Idiom (Tuvalu): Ko te tagata galue malosi, e maua te manuia
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: If you work hard, you will succeed.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Widely used in Tuvalu as moral instruction to youth.
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Tuvalu): ko te taˈgata ɡaˈlue maˈlosi e ˈmaua te maˈnuia
First Example Sentence: Ko taku matua e fai mai, ‘Ko te tagata galue malosi, e maua te manuia.’
Second Example Sentence: E fakamaoni ne te lalolagi te mea tenei – e maua te manuia.
Third Example Sentence: E fiafia te faiako o fai atu, ‘Ko te tagata galue malosi, e maua te manuia.’

Idiom (Tuvalu): E se gata te poto i te tusi fua
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Wisdom is not limited to book learning.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Reflects oral wisdom traditions emphasizing practical experience.
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Tuvalu): e se ˈŋata te ˈpoto i te ˈtusi ˈfua
First Example Sentence: Ko te faiako ne fai atu, ‘E se gata te poto i te tusi fua.’
Second Example Sentence: E iloa ne tatou, e se gata te poto i te tusi fua.
Third Example Sentence: Ko te tagata poto e iloa ne ia me e se gata te poto i te tusi fua.

Idiom (Tuvalu): E maua te filemu i loto i te loto mālie
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Inner peace comes from a kind heart.
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: Peace comes from kindness and calmness.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Used in religious and community contexts, tied to Christian teaching.
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Tuvalu): e ˈmaua te fiˈlemu i ˈloto i te ˈloto ˈmaːlie
First Example Sentence: E maua te filemu i loto i te loto mālie, e pei o te fakafetai.
Second Example Sentence: Ko taku matua e fai mai, ‘E maua te filemu i loto i te loto mālie.’
Third Example Sentence: E se maua te filemu māfana ki se loto masaua; e maua i loto mālie.

Idiom (Tuvalu): Ko te manuia e se maua i te nofo noa
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Success does not come to those who are idle.
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: You must act to achieve something.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Traditional Tuvalu work ethic idiom passed through generations.
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Tuvalu): ko te maˈnuia e se ˈmaua i te ˈnofo ˈnoa
First Example Sentence: Ko te faiako e fai atu, ‘Ko te manuia e se maua i te nofo noa.’
Second Example Sentence: E iloa ne tatou katoa – e se maua i te nofo noa.
Third Example Sentence: Ko taku matua e toe fai, ‘Ko te manuia e se maua i te nofo noa.’

Idiom (Tuvalu): E lavea ne te taimi te loto tonu
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: People’s true nature shows over time.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Rooted in Tuvaluan oratory traditions emphasizing patience and truth.
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Tuvalu): e laˈβea ne te ˈtaimi te ˈloto ˈtonu
First Example Sentence: E lavea ne te taimi te loto tonu o tagata.
Second Example Sentence: E se mafai o fakalilifu te mea pepelo; e lavea ne te taimi.
Third Example Sentence: Ko taku matua e fai mai, ‘E lavea ne te taimi te loto tonu.’
